Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Preserving a Unique Archive for Long-Term Solar Variability Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a short-term (one-year) effort to preserve and digitize a set of hand-drawn charts going back more than 40 years of solar features identified from Hydrogen-alpha images of the Sun. They were defined in 1964 as a means to identify and track major magnetic structures on the surface of the Sun and their evolution. This was before modern measurements of solar magnetism were routinely available. They were produced consistently and continually through 2010 and have formed the basis for important discoveries about solar magnetic field and surface evolution. However, this valuable resource is now in imminent danger of being lost because the scientist in charge and his two assistants, who were trained by him and worked with him on the maps, have retired. They are the only people with intimate knowledge of the technique behind the charts. Furthermore, while much of the original data set has been saved in their homes, is has not otherwise been preserved in copies or in digital form. Nor is it protected from loss through flooding, fire, etc. The main purpose of this RAPID award is to ensure that the entire set of charts is organized, scanned and digitally processed using a consistent, machine-readable format, thus creating a readily accessible dataset that can be utilized scientifically for years to come. The two assistants will carry out the majority of the effort, in collaboration with solar physics scientist and experts in the scanning, digital processing and data archiving of scientific data. The final digitized, searchable maps will be archived at NOAA's National Geophysical Data Center.

This set of synoptic maps constitutes a unique and significant observational resource on the evolution of large-scale solar features over the course of four solar cycles. Once digitized, they can be used to measure the proportions of the solar surface exhibiting specific phenomena, and the locations of these features as a function of latitude and longitude (as defined by pixel location). The data can then be used to evaluate the proportions and their changes over time. This will provide extremely useful information that can be used to test theories and models for predicting the Sun's activity as a whole over a single cycle or over numerous cycles. It will also be useful for a wealth of other studies concerning specific features at the Sun, such as filaments, coronal holes or plage regions, as well as their variations over time in terms of quantity, location or movement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

In 1964 (Solar Cycle 20) Patrick McIntosh began creating hand-drawn synoptic maps of solar activity, based on H-alpha imaging measurements. These synoptic maps were unique because they traced the polarity inversion lines, connecting widely separated filaments, fibril patterns and corridors within active areas to reveal the large-scale organization of the solar magnetic field. McIntosh and his assistants created these synoptic maps for each Carrington Rotation (CR) during the interval 1964-2009, with the exception of a 2-year period from July 1974-July 1976. Thus, the synoptic maps cover ~45 years or ~570 CRs, or nearly four complete solar cycles (SCs). The features on the maps include filaments, large-scale positive and negative polarity regions, coronal holes of each polarity, sunspots and active regions (Figure-top). The McIntosh map collection is unique, providing a consistent view of the evolution of the global solar field.

Although Pat McIntosh is now deceased, Ian Hewins and Robert McFadden were trained in the mapping by Pat from 2000-2010, and have preserved all the mapping materials. Under this grant we have preserved the original data and organized, scanned and digitally processed the maps using a consistent, machine-readable format, thus creating an archive that may be utilized scientists and the public for years to come. The processed maps are output as files of arrays of numbers, which reproduce color-coded solar features for each rotation (Figure-bottom). A spreadsheet contains information about, e.g., data sources and cartographic notes, and is maintained for all processed maps. A computer program, plotfinal.pro, makes plots from the input files for the synoptic maps for a given CR.

These maps provide a significant measurement of the evolution of large-scale solar features over the course of four solar cycles. The digitized maps can be used to measure the proportions of the solar surface exhibiting specific phenomena, and the locations of these features as a function of latitude and longitude. The data can then be used to graph the proportions and their changes over time. This information is useful in predicting the Sun’s activity as a whole over a single solar cycle or over numerous cycles. It is also useful for studying certain features and their variations over time in terms of quantity, location or movement.

The procedure developed during the grant was to scan the original CR McIntosh maps at NCAR/HAO. “Level0” gif images are Photoshop-processed gif images made from pdf scans of each hand-drawn CR map.  “Level1” gif images have been cropped, oriented and scaled for consistency. The goal of completing all of the Level0 and Level1 data sets for all of the original maps, 1964-2009, except for the gap from mid-1974 to mid-1976, has been accomplished. The final processing of the electronic maps is called “Level3”. The goal of completing the processed maps for all of SC 23, from 1996 into 2009, has also been accomplished. We then worked backwards in time and SC number until the grant ended on 28 February 2017. At that time nearly half of the ~570 CR maps had been completed, from mid-SC 21 to the start of SC 24 with the long gap from mid- to end-SC 22. All maps, in original scanned format and final processed format, are archived at NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI).

Intellectual Merit

The digitally-processed maps are an extremely useful tool for improving our understanding of the drift of polar crown filaments and the solar magnetic field reversals, the evolution of CHs, and the morphology of coronal cavities. The scientific objective of this effort is to utilize the completed archive to investigate long-term solar variability over up to 4 solar cycles. In particular, the archive allows study of the correlated evolution of open and closed magnetic structures over multiple time scales.  Such studies are important for understanding the solar dynamo, the sources and evolution of active regions, CHs, filaments and variations with respect to solar differential rotation, hemisphere, and among solar cycles.

Broader Impacts

The digitally-processed maps will be a very useful tool for improving our understanding of and ability to predict solar activity and space weather. Such predictions are needed to protect assets vital to our national security and the operations of technologies used worldwide in civilian daily life.  An accurate baseline of solar activity that covers four consecutive SCs can significantly enhance our prediction capability.  In addition, improving public access to historic measurements of CHs and filaments will enable researchers to better understand and study the connection between these phenomena at the Sun and their effects at Earth. The original and processed final maps for each CR map are publically available at the NOAA/NCEI. We will continue to make announcements to the community as new maps are added to the archive, and as we develop new analysis tools for the proposed effort.
